The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.

Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$. If $G$ is a group, $H$ is called a subgroup of $G$ if in addition, (iii) $a \in H \Longrightarrow a^{-1} \in H$. In particular, a subgroup of a group $G$ is a submonoid that is closed under the process of taking inverses. In defining a subgroup $H \subset G$, condition (i) can be weakened by simply requiring $H \neq \emptyset$, since this implies $e \in H$ using (ii) and (iii). Of course, similar reasoning is not possible for monoids. Every group $G$ admits $\{e\}$ and $G$ as trivial subgroups. Given $m \in \mathbb{Z}$, the set $m \mathbb{Z}$ consisting of all integral multiples of $m$ is a subgroup of the additive group $\mathbb{Z}$. We will see in 1.3/4 that all subgroups of $\mathbb{Z}$ are of this type. More generally, every element $a$ of a group $G$ gives rise to a so-called cyclic subgroup of $G$. It consists of all powers $a^{n}, n \in \mathbb{Z}$, where we put $a^{n}=\left(a^{-1}\right)^{-n}$ for $n<0; see also Section 1.3.
Does the concept of a/an Order of a group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Subgroup to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a subgroup does not inherently require the concept of the order of a group. A subgroup is defined based on structural properties within the group, specifically: closure under the group operation, the existence of an identity element, and closure under taking inverses. These criteria ensure that the subset forms a group under the same operation as the parent group. The order of a group, on the other hand, refers to the number of elements in the group, which is a quantitative measure rather than a structural or operational characteristic. Therefore, understanding or defining a subgroup does not depend on knowing the order of the group; it solely depends on the group's operational and structural properties. Thus, the concept of the order of a group is not necessary for the definition of a subgroup to make sense.
